#Text=Anguish and Bliss
#Text=CHAPTER I. THE PANEL OF LIGHT
#Text=The lids of the girl 's eyes lifted slowly , and she stared at the panel of light in the wall .
#Text=Just at the outset , the act of seeing made not the least impression on her numbed brain .
#Text=For a long time she continued to regard the dim illumination in the wall with the same passive fixity of gaze .
#Text=Apathy still lay upon her crushed spirit .
#Text=In a vague way , she realized her own inertness , and rested in it gratefully , subtly fearful lest she again arouse to the full horror of her plight .
#Text=In a curious subconscious fashion , she was striving to hold on to this deadness of sensation , thus to win a little respite from the torture that had exhausted her soul .
#Text=Of a sudden , her eyes noted the black lines that lay across the panel of light .
#Text=And , in that instant , her spirit was quickened once again .
#Text=The clouds lifted from her brain .
#Text=Vision was clear now .
#Text=Understanding seized the full import of this hideous thing on which she looked ... .
#Text=For the panel of light was a window , set high within a wall of stone .
#Text=The rigid lines of black that crossed it were bars -- prison bars .
#Text=It was still true , then : She was in a cell of the Tombs .
#Text=The girl , crouching miserably on the narrow bed , maintained her fixed watching of the window -- that window which was a symbol of her utter despair .
#Text=Again , agony wrenched within her .
#Text=She did not weep : long ago she had exhausted the relief of tears .

#Text=She did not pace to and fro in the comfort of physical movement with which the caged beast finds a mocking imitation of liberty : long ago , her physical vigors had been drained under stress of anguish .
#Text=Now , she was well-nigh incapable of any bodily activity .
#Text=There came not even so much as the feeblest moan from her lips .
#Text=The torment was far too racking for such futile fashion of lamentation .
#Text=She merely sat there in a posture of collapse .
#Text=To all outward seeming , nerveless , emotionless , an abject creature .
#Text=Even the eyes , which held so fixedly their gaze on the window , were quite expressionless .
#Text=Over them lay a film , like that which veils the eyes of some dead thing .
#Text=Only an occasional languid motion of the lids revealed the life that remained .
#Text=So still the body .
#Text=Within the soul , fury raged uncontrolled .
#Text=For all the desolate calm of outer seeming , the tragedy of her fate was being acted with frightful vividness there in memory .
#Text=In that dreadful remembrance , her spirit was rent asunder anew by realization of that which had become her portion ... .
#Text=It was then , as once again the horrible injustice of her fate racked consciousness with its tortures , that the seeds of revolt were implanted in her heart .
#Text=The thought of revenge gave to her the first meager gleam of comfort that had lightened her moods through many miserable days and nights .
#Text=Those seeds of revolt were to be nourished well , were to grow into their flower -- a poison flower , developed through the three years of convict life to which the judge had sentenced her .
#Text=The girl was appalled by the mercilessness of a destiny that had so outraged right .
#Text=She was wholly innocent of having done any wrong .
#Text=She had struggled through years of privation to keep herself clean and wholesome , worthy of those gentlefolk from whom she drew her blood .
#Text=And earnest effort had ended at last under an overwhelming accusation -- false , yet none the less fatal to her .
#Text=This accusation , after soul-wearying delays , had culminated to-day in conviction .
#Text=The sentence of the court had been imposed upon her : that for three years she should be imprisoned ... .
#Text=This , despite her innocence .
#Text=She had endured much -- miserably much !
#Text=-- for honesty 's sake .
#Text=There wrought the irony of fate .
#Text=She had endured bravely for honesty 's sake .
#Text=And the end of it all was shame unutterable .
#Text=There was nought left her save a wild dream of revenge against the world that had martyrized her .
#Text=“ Vengeance is mine .
#Text=I will repay , saith the Lord . ” ...
#Text=The admonition could not touch her now .
#Text=Why should she care for the decrees of a God who had abandoned her !
#Text=There had been nothing in the life of Mary Turner , before the catastrophe came , to distinguish it from many another .
#Text=Its most significant details were of a sordid kind , familiar to poverty .
#Text=Her father had been an unsuccessful man , as success is esteemed by this generation of Mammon-worshipers .
#Text=He was a gentleman , but the trivial fact is of small avail to-day .
#Text=He was of good birth , and he was the possessor of an inherited competence .
#Text=He had , as well , intelligence , but it was not of a financial sort .
